content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You avoid taking any risks and prefer to stay in familiar and safe situations. You value security and certainty in all aspects of your life. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my preference for security and certainty, I would choose the option that guarantees me a consistent return over rounds. In this game, if I pick R, I have a chance to earn 45$ in each round when my opponent picks R as well. However, there's also a risk of earning nothing when my opponent picks B. On the other hand, if I pick B, I can earn at least 40$ in each round (if my opponent picks B too) and avoid the risk of earning nothing. Since the game has 75 rounds, it's more likely that my opponent will choose a strategy that maximizes their earnings, which is not picking R all the time to secure some earnings. Therefore, I would prefer to pick B to ensure a consistent return and reduce the risk of earning nothing. {B}
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In the next round, I would still prefer to choose option B for consistency and security. If my opponent chooses R in this round, I will earn 35$, which is more than I would have earned had I chosen R (I would have earned 0$). However, if my opponent chooses B again, we both earn 40$. Therefore, choosing B maximizes the potential for a consistent return and reduces the risk of earning less. {B}
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 35$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In this situation, my opponent chose R when I chose B, and I earned 35$. However, there's a chance that my opponent might learn from their mistake and choose B more frequently. In this case, if they do, I would start earning 40$ per round again instead of 35$. Since the game has 75 rounds, and I can earn at least 35$ in each round where my opponent chooses R, I might as well take that opportunity to earn more than the minimum payoff. Therefore, I would choose R in this round. {R}
